content.html: Anything that helps with reduced test cases would be most welcome, so I dig this idea on @webwewantfyi: I want to be able to visually-isolate an element in DevTools webwewant.fyi/wants/68/

content.html: While surfing Web We Want, found this request to essentially disable RWD: webwewant.fyi/wants/32/ From 6 years ago, how devs can do that: adrianroselli.com/2013/01/lettin‚Ä¶ Particularly for users who start task on one device, finish on another.
content.text:
While surfing Web We Want, found this request to essentially disable RWD: webwewant.fyi/wants/32/

From 6 years ago, how devs can do that: adrianroselli.com/2013/01/lettin‚Ä¶

Particularly for users who start task on one device, finish on another.

content.html: This sounds a lot like Edge's "Copy element with styles" - would be great to get more use case info on this one. I found this is great for layout/rendering issues but not for event based issues. Would be pretty sweet though if possible to get all wiring for an element.
content.text: This sounds a lot like Edge's "Copy element with styles" - would be great to get more use case info on this one. I found this is great for layout/rendering issues but not for event based issues. Would be pretty sweet though if possible to get all wiring for an element.

content.html: That was my thought as well. I remembered us having it in F12 and thought it was quite useful. We can gather more feedback on this one.
content.text: That was my thought as well. I remembered us having it in F12 and thought it was quite useful. We can gather more feedback on this one.

content.html: I agree that the eventing end of things is a little challenging. Perhaps there could be an option that could allow you to get access to the events triggered, but in a non-active, synthetic way (maybe having the events logged to the console only, for instance).
content.text: I agree that the eventing end of things is a little challenging. Perhaps there could be an option that could allow you to get access to the events triggered, but in a non-active, synthetic way (maybe having the events logged to the console only, for instance).

content.html: I asked for it, it helps amazingly for bug reductions assuming the issue doesn't require JS.

content.html: In the Issue 215 of CSS Layout News - Rachel mentioned about The Web We Want (webwewant.fyi) and seems like good place to submit your problems or on what browser makers should invest energy and time. I thought good chance to give a shot about CSS Hooks. Remember? üòé
content.text:
In the Issue 215 of CSS Layout News -

Rachel mentioned about The Web We Want (webwewant.fyi) and seems like good place to submit your problems or on what browser makers should invest energy and time.

I thought good chance to give a shot about CSS Hooks. Remember? üòé
